articles.headline: Teeth Gritted, Drivers Adjust to $4 Gasoline
articles.snippet: Americans are giving up their gas guzzlers, making fewer trips to the mall and even riding public transportation.
articles.abstract: Americans are giving up their gas guzzlers, making fewer trips to the mall and even riding public transportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hating every minute of it, Americans are slowly learning to live with high gasoline prices. For a nation accustomed to cheap fuel, big vehicles and sprawling suburbs, the adjustments are wrenching.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Mireya Navarro

articles.headline: Cable Prices Keep Rising, and Customers Keep Paying
articles.snippet: The resiliency of cable in the Internet age is remarkable considering that prices have risen 77 percent since 1996.
articles.abstract: The resiliency of cable in the Internet age is remarkable considering that prices have risen 77 percent since 1996.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans discouraged by higher gas prices and airline fares may decide to spend more vacation time at home, perhaps watching television.

articles.headline: 270 Illegal Immigrants Sent to Prison in Federal Push
articles.snippet: Immigrants arrested in an Iowa raid faced tough criminal charges instead of rapid deportation, signaling a sharp escalation in a Bush administration crackdown.
articles.abstract: Immigrants arrested in an Iowa raid faced tough criminal charges instead of rapid deportation, signaling a sharp escalation in a Bush administration crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa  In temporary courtrooms at a fairgrounds here, 260 illegal immigrants were sentenced this week to five months in prison for working at a meatpacking plant with false documents.

articles.headline: China’s Rush to Dispose of Dead Compounds Agony
articles.snippet: Family members have not been able to identify relatives and traditional reverence for the deceased has been upset.
articles.abstract: Family members have not been able to identify relatives and traditional reverence for the deceased has been upset.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEICHUAN, China  The 30 bodies in plastic bags lay strewn outside the tea factory at the foot of the forensic scientist, flies buzzing all around. From some he had collected molars, and from others cartilage. He had worked quickly, 20 minutes per body.

articles.headline: Existing Home Sales Fell in April to Another Low
articles.snippet: Sales of previously owned homes, which make up the bulk of the housing market, dipped 1 percent last month, according to the National Association of Realtors.
articles.abstract: Sales of previously owned homes, which make up the bulk of the housing market, dipped 1 percent last month, according to the National Association of Realtors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks took a dive on Friday after a report confirmed fears that the housing slump, which has weighed on nearly every corner of the nation’s economy, was nowhere near its end.

articles.headline: McCain’s Health Is Called Robust by His Doctors
articles.snippet: John McCain is in excellent health and shows no evidence of a recurrence of the melanoma that led to head and neck surgery in 2000, his doctors said.
articles.abstract: John McCain is in excellent health and shows no evidence of a recurrence of the melanoma that led to head and neck surgery in 2000, his doctors said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Senator John McCain, 71, is in excellent health and shows no evidence of the recurrence of the melanoma skin cancer that led to extensive head and neck surgery in 2000, Mr. McCain’s doctors said Friday.
articles.byline: By Lawrence K. Altman and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Cellphone Pioneer Struggles to Stay Relevant
articles.snippet: Motorola’s reversal of fortunes has been striking, with a global market share of the cellular phone market below 10 percent, a plunge from 22 percent in 2006.
articles.abstract: Motorola’s reversal of fortunes has been striking, with a global market share of the cellular phone market below 10 percent, a plunge from 22 percent in 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neeraj Choubey has not worked at the troubled cellphone maker Motorola for seven years. But from the number of calls and e-mail messages Mr. Choubey, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, has gotten in recent weeks, you would think he had never left his old colleagues.

articles.headline: LifeLock Identity Fraud Service Finds Skeptics
articles.snippet: How likely is it that an identity thief can do you real harm? And do you need to pay $100 a year for protection?
articles.abstract: How likely is it that an identity thief can do you real harm? And do you need to pay $100 a year for protection?
articles.lead_paragraph: It is, without a doubt, one of the great marketing stunts in recent memory.

articles.headline: Clinton Remark on Kennedy’s Killing Stirs Uproar
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed regret about a remark that brought up concern for Barack Obama’s safety.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed regret about a remark that brought up concern for Barack Obama’s safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRANDON, S.D.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defended staying in the Democratic nominating contest on Friday by pointing out that her husband had not wrapped up the nomination until June 1992, adding, “We all remember Bobby Kennedy was assassinated in June in California.”

articles.headline: The Sinatra of Southwest Feels the Love
articles.snippet: American and Southwest hold shareholder meetings on the same day, but the gatherings couldn’t be more different.
articles.abstract: American and Southwest hold shareholder meetings on the same day, but the gatherings couldn’t be more different.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Dallas-Fort Worth area is home to two of the country’s biggest airlines, American and Southwest, and for years, they’ve both held their annual meetings on the same day. This year was no exception: Wednesday was the big day.

articles.headline: Chinese Are Left to Ask Why Schools Crumbled
articles.snippet: A staggering number of students died as schools collapsed in the May 12 earthquake, and grieving parents are speaking out about shoddy construction.
articles.abstract: A staggering number of students died as schools collapsed in the May 12 earthquake, and grieving parents are speaking out about shoddy construction.
articles.lead_paragraph: This story was reported by Jim Yardley, Jake Hooker and Andrew C. Revkin, and was written by Mr. Yardley.

articles.headline: Toughest Summer Job This Year Is Finding One
articles.snippet: The job market of 2008 is shaping up as the weakest in 50 years for teenagers seeking summer work.
articles.abstract: The job market of 2008 is shaping up as the weakest in 50 years for teenagers seeking summer work.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla.  School is out, and Aaron Stallings, his junior year of high school behind him, wanders the air-conditioned cocoon of the Woodland Hills Mall in search of a job.

articles.headline: Gauging the Big Bets of a Hot Hand
articles.snippet: Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurance company, owes its performance less to its core operations and more to its derivative gains. But some of its positions raise questions for the future.
articles.abstract: Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurance company, owes its performance less to its core operations and more to its derivative gains. But some of its positions raise questions for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: COME hell, high water, credit crisis or asbestos claims, Fairfax Financial Holdings is that rarity  an insurance company whose shares have stood tall through it all. Even as the Standard & Poor’s insurance composite index has fallen 17.6 percent this year, Fairfax’s stock is down just 2.1 percent.

articles.headline: Worries in G.O.P. About McCain Camp Disarray
articles.snippet: Some party leaders are worried about whether Senator John McCain has taken full advantage of Democratic turmoil.
articles.abstract: Some party leaders are worried about whether Senator John McCain has taken full advantage of Democratic turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign is in a troubled stretch, hindered by resignations of staff members, a lagging effort to build a national campaign organization and questions over whether he has taken full advantage of Democratic turmoil to present a case for his candidacy, Republicans say.

articles.headline: Rendering Justice, With One Eye on Re-election
articles.snippet: While most of the world tries to insulate judges from popular will, many in the United States are elected.
articles.abstract: While most of the world tries to insulate judges from popular will, many in the United States are elected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Wisconsin voters did something that is routine in the United States but virtually unknown in the rest of the world: They elected a judge.

articles.headline: Wall Street Exodus: Fear, Panic and Anger
articles.snippet: Investment bankers, recruiters and psychologists say the current economic downturn, the cascade of layoffs and grim financial news have exacted an especially daunting psychic price.
articles.abstract: Investment bankers, recruiters and psychologists say the current economic downturn, the cascade of layoffs and grim financial news have exacted an especially daunting psychic price.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE mind wraps itself around losing a job, one of life’s great traumas, in jagged and swerving fits. When the call comes in, when rumor turns to reality, when it’s not the broker in the next cubicle but you who is presented with a stack of severance papers, the psyche takes over.

articles.headline: Global Dreams for a Wireless Web
articles.snippet: An entrepreneur is trying to cover the Earth with Web access, one hot spot at a time. But his big idea is encountering equally big obstacles.
articles.abstract: An entrepreneur is trying to cover the Earth with Web access, one hot spot at a time. But his big idea is encountering equally big obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Menorca, Spain

articles.headline: States Chafing at U.S. Focus on Terrorism
articles.snippet: State and local officials say federal financing for domestic security is too closely tied to combating terrorist threats.
articles.abstract: State and local officials say federal financing for domestic security is too closely tied to combating terrorist threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Juliette N. Kayyem, the Massachusetts homeland security adviser, was in her office in early February when an aide brought her startling news. To qualify for its full allotment of federal money, Massachusetts had to come up with a plan to protect the state from an almost unheard-of threat: improvised explosive devices, known as I.E.D.’s.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David Johnston

articles.headline: The Wars We Choose to Ignore
articles.snippet: Coverage of the Iraq war tapered off even as the body count remained high.
articles.abstract: Coverage of the Iraq war tapered off even as the body count remained high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gen. John A. Logan was a Union officer, a fierce Republican partisan, an early advocate of the kind of volunteer army the United States now fights wars with. He is also one of the people credited with coming up with the holiday that we celebrate today. A statue in Logan Circle in Washington shows the general on horseback flanked by two female figures said to represent America at war and America at peace.

articles.headline: Browsers Are a Battleground Once Again
articles.snippet: Browser developer Mozilla will soon release Firefox 3.0, which will feature a few tricks that could change the way people organize and find the Web sites they visit most frequently.
articles.abstract: Browser developer Mozilla will soon release Firefox 3.0, which will feature a few tricks that could change the way people organize and find the Web sites they visit most frequently.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The browser, that porthole onto the broad horizon of the Web, is about to get some fancy new window dressing.

articles.headline: A Few Tremors in Oprahland
articles.snippet: The average audience for “The Oprah Winfrey Show” has fallen nearly 7 percent this year, according to Nielsen Media Research — its third straight year of decline.
articles.abstract: The average audience for “The Oprah Winfrey Show” has fallen nearly 7 percent this year, according to Nielsen Media Research — its third straight year of decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Oprah Winfrey is still the queen of all media, but her crown is beginning to look a bit tarnished.

articles.headline: Warner Tries a New Tactic to Revive Its DVD Sales
articles.snippet: Warner Brothers Entertainment is trying to boost DVD sagging sales by releasing companion projects to its films exclusively on DVD.
articles.abstract: Warner Brothers Entertainment is trying to boost DVD sagging sales by releasing companion projects to its films exclusively on DVD.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Retail’s love affair with the DVD is on the rocks and Warner Brothers Entertainment would like to patch things up.

articles.headline: Tax Exemptions of Charities Face New Challenges
articles.snippet: The Minnesota Supreme Court’s ruling that a day care agency had to pay taxes because it essentially gave nothing away has alarmed nonprofit groups.
articles.abstract: The Minnesota Supreme Court’s ruling that a day care agency had to pay taxes because it essentially gave nothing away has alarmed nonprofit groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: RED WING, Minn.  Authorities from the local tax assessor to members of Congress are increasingly challenging the tax-exempt status of nonprofit institutions  ranging from small group homes to wealthy universities  questioning whether they deserve special treatment.

articles.headline: Mexico’s War Against Drugs Kills Its Police
articles.snippet: President Felipe Calderón’s vow to end police corruption and drug-related violence has turned into a street war in which no attack has been too brazen for the gangs.
articles.abstract: President Felipe Calderón’s vow to end police corruption and drug-related violence has turned into a street war in which no attack has been too brazen for the gangs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  The assassination was an inside job. The federal police commander kept his schedule secret and slept in a different place each night, yet the killer had the keys to the official’s apartment and was waiting for him when he arrived after midnight.

articles.headline: After Years of Turmoil, Newsday Prepares for Another Owner
articles.snippet: As Cablevision gets ready to take over Newsday, the paper’s readers and journalists are debating whether it means continued shrinkage, an infusion of new resources or something in between.
articles.abstract: As Cablevision gets ready to take over Newsday, the paper’s readers and journalists are debating whether it means continued shrinkage, an infusion of new resources or something in between.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, Newsday belonged to the front rank of American journalism. It reached far beyond its original role as chronicler of Long Island, covered news worldwide, undertook big reporting projects and even had the audacity to take on the New York City market.

articles.headline: Clinton Could Face an Uneasy Return to the Senate
articles.snippet: More of the Senate’s Democratic members favored Barack Obama over Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.abstract: More of the Senate’s Democratic members favored Barack Obama over Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Hillary Rodham Clinton made a rare stop in the Senate last week, she spoke from a lonely outpost at the end of the Armed Services Committee dais, eight empty chairs emphasizing the gulf between her and real Senate power at the chairman’s spot.

articles.headline: Weeks After Cyclone in Myanmar, Even Farmers Wait for Food
articles.snippet: The roads of the ravaged Irrawaddy Delta are lined with hungry people who have lost everything.
articles.abstract: The roads of the ravaged Irrawaddy Delta are lined with hungry people who have lost everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: PYAPON, Myanmar  The roads of the ravaged Irrawaddy Delta are lined these days with people hoping to be fed.
